Research Paper Nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon as metal-free catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of alcohols Xiangzhu Yu Writing – original draft Investigation Conceptualization 1 Ling Ni Formal analysis Data curation 1 Enshuang Bai Formal analysis Meng Miao Investigation Xinyue Tang Methodology Lianyue Wang Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Liaoning Normal University, Dalian 116029, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Liaoning Normal University Dalian 116029 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Liaoning Normal University, Dalian 116029, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally. The selective oxidation of alcohols to carbonyl compounds is a crucial reaction in organic chemistry. In this study, we report the synthesis of nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon material by hard template method using biomass derivative sucrose and melamine as carbon and nitrogen sources and silica sol as template agent. Using molecular oxygen as the oxidant, the obtained NC-900 exhibits excellent selectivity in the oxidation of primary alcohols to the corresponding aldehydes without generating over-oxidized acid. For example, under optimal reaction conditions, 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol is almost quantitatively converted to 4-methoxybenzaldehyde. The catalytic system showed robust tolerance to sensitive functional groups and demonstrated favorable reaction effects in gram-scale experiments and multi-step, one-pot reaction sequences. The catalyst was reused for 5 times, and its catalytic activity did not decrease significantly. Hammett correlation studies indicated that the reaction favored substrates with electron-donating substituents. Characterization and experimental results indicate that the synergistic effect of graphitic N and mesoporous structure plays a pivotal role in enhancing the catalytic activity of NC-900 in this transformation. The mechanism study shows that the reaction involves free radical process. Graphical abstract Oxidative synthesis of carbonyl compounds from alcohols catalyzed by heterogeneous metal-free biomass-derived carbon material using molecular oxygen as the oxidizing agent is described. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass-derived N-doped carbon Mesoporous material Metal-free Alcohols oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective oxidation of alcohols is an important reaction in organic synthetic chemistry, and its product carbonyl compounds (aldehydes or ketones) are widely used in various fields such as pharmaceuticals, plastic additives, cosmetics, and dyes [1-4]. Traditional oxidation methods primarily rely on stoichiometric oxidants, including potassium dichromate, chromium trioxide, manganese dioxide, pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC), and pyridinium dichromate (PDC) to achieve this oxidative conversion [5,6]. Although traditional oxidation methods have been used, a large number of by-products are produced during the reaction process, making them inconsistent with modern green chemistry principles. In recent years, significant progress has been made in modern catalytic oxidation methods, in which the main catalysts include noble metal catalysts (Au, Ag, Pd, Ru) [7-10], non-noble metal catalysts (Mn, Co, Cu, Fe) [11-15], and non-metal catalysts (nitroxyl radicals, DDQ, NHPI) [16-20]. These catalysts can effectively achieve aerobic oxidationof alcohols. From an environmental and economic perspective, metal-based catalysts suffer from limitations such as limited metal resources, metal leaching, poor stability, and heavy metal contamination in products, limiting their applications in the pharmaceutical and biomedical fields. Non-metal catalysts also have some disadvantages, including complex reaction systems, intricate post-treatment procedures, and the inability to recycle and reuse. Therefore, developing cost-effective and highly selective catalytic oxidation methods for alcohols has been a research focus from the perspectives of green chemistry and atom economy. In recent years, carbon materials with environmental friendliness, excellent stability, and adjustable surface functionality have increasingly found applications in organic catalysis [21-25]. Typically, heteroatoms, especially nitrogen atoms, are introduced to replace some carbon atoms in the matrix to adjust the properties of the materials and alter the surface charge distribution, thereby creating active centers with catalytic functions [26-29]. In the context, a series of N-doped carbon-based materials have been developed for catalyzing the oxidation of alcohols to carbonyl compounds [30-33,35-40]. For example, Feng Peng and co-workers developed nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) as carbon-based catalysts for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde with adding HNO3 as a promoter [30]. Xuxu Wang and co-workers reported that N-doped graphene nanosheets can catalyze the oxidation of benzylic alcohols, with graphitic sp² N species recognized as the active centers [31]. Weitao Wang and co-workers described a N and O dual-doped carboncatalyst prepared from quinone-amine polymers exhibiting improving catalytic efficiency for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde in water [32]. Masahiko Arai and co-workers demonstrated that N-doped activated carbon catalysts showedactivity for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol, and graphitic N species play a crucial role in the formation of active sites on the AC surface [33]. Shi and co-workers reported that carbon materials effectively catalyze the preparation of high value-added products from alcohol compounds through the hydrogen borrowing reaction mechanism [34]. Although carbon-based catalysts have achieved good results in the selective oxidation of alcohols, the substrate range of most catalyst systems is limite, and there are few reports of nitrogen-doped carbon materials derived from biomass, and they usually show unsatisfactory catalytic activity as control experiments in nitrogen-phosphorus co-doped catalysts [41,42]. Based on recent research and interest in catalytic systems of nitrogen-doped carbon materials [43], we further explore the preparation of non-metallic nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts and their application in catalyzing alcohol oxidation reactions. Herein, we synthesize nitrogen-doped carbon material NC-900 with mesoporous structure through a hard-template method, using biomass derivative sucrose and melamine as raw materials. The prepared NC-900 exhibits excellent catalytic performance in the oxidation of primary alcohols to the corresponding aldehydes with molecular oxygen as the oxidant. In comparison with previously reported metal-free catalytic systems, the individual nitrogen-doped carbon material still maintains high selectivity and yield, without the generation of over-oxidized acid compounds. This catalytic system exhibits good tolerance to sensitive functional groups such as allyl and propargyl groups and demonstrates favorable reaction effects in gram-scale experiments and multi-step, one-pot reaction sequences. Hammett correlation studies verify that the reaction is more favorable for substrates containing electron-donating substituents. The characterization and experimental results indicate that the enhanced catalytic activity exhibited by the catalyst in this transformation arises from the synergistic interaction between graphitic N and the advanced mesoporous structure. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Procedure for the preparation of the NC-X catalysts Solution A contains sucrose (0.85 g) and melamine (0.85 g) in 10 mL of distilled water under stirring conditions at room temperature. Solution B contains LUDOX®AS-40 colloidal silica (2.5 g) in 40 mL distilled water. Then, solution A was dropwise added to solution B and the whole reaction mixture was heated at 110 °C for 4 h, and then water was evaporated through heating. The obtained solid was ground into powder and pyrolyzed at 900 °C (or 600, 700, 800 °C) for 2 h under N2 atmosphere. After cooling to room temperature, the silica template was removed using 8 mL of 5 mol/L NH₄HF₂. The etched samples were then thoroughly rinsed with distilled water until the wash water reached a neutral pH and were dried overnight at 110 °C. The mesoporous carbon materials were donated as NC-X (X = pyrolysis temperature). 2.2 General procedure for the synthesis of aldehydes 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol (0.25 mmol), NC-900 (30 mg), and acetonitrile (6 mL) were added into a reaction glass vial equipped with a magnetic stirring bar and a septum cap. Subsequently, the reaction vial was placed into an autoclave, and the autoclave was pressurized with molecular oxygen to a pressure of 0.1 MPa. The reaction mixture was stirred at 130 °C for 24 hours. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. The residual oxygen was discharged, and the sample was removed from the autoclave. Biphenyl was added to the glass vial as a standard, and the reaction product was diluted with acetonitrile. After filtering, the diluted product was analyzed using gas chromatography (GC) and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance To evaluate the catalytic performances of the nitrogen-doped carbon material for the aerobic oxidation of alcohols, 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol (1a) was selected as a model substrate (Table 1 ). The blank experiment indicated that the reaction did not proceed in the absence of a catalyst (Table 1, entry 1). The pyrolysis temperature employed during catalyst preparation significantly influenced the reactivity (Table 1, entries 2–5), with NC-900 exhibiting the most superior performance. when the template SiO2 was not removed, only a trace of 2a was obtained (Table 1, entry 6), indicating that the pore structure in the catalyst is primarily responsible for this reaction. The un-doped mesoporous carbon as catalysts for the reaction showed lower activity (Table 1, entry 7). Reducing the amount of catalyst resulted in a decreased yield of 3a (Table 1, entries 8, 9), and the necessity of O2 for the conversion process was confirmed (Table 1, entry 10). In addition, solvent exploration experiments indicated that acetonitrile acts as a favorable selectivity for 3a. (Table 1, entries 2, 11–18). 3.2 Catalyst characterization The structural characteristics of NC-X were investigated through X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy. Two prominent broad peaks were observed at 25° and 43° in the XRD pattern of NC-900, corresponding to 002 and 100 faces of graphitic carbon formed during high-temperature pyrolysis (Fig. 1a ) [44]. Raman spectroscopy revealed two distinct peaks attributed to disordered carbon (D band) and crystalline graphite carbon (G band), respectively. With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, it is observed that the I D/I G ratio of NC-X also increases from 2.28 to 3.01, indicating that the internal defect and disorder density of NC-900 material is the highest. As the exhibited the best catalytic performance catalyst, the I D/I G of NC-900 decreased from 3.01 to 2.65 after five cycles of reuse. This decrease may be attributed to carbon sintering, resulting in fewer defects in carbon materials (Fig. 1b) [45]. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) reveals that the surface of NC-900 exhibits a blocky and irregular morphology. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) displays structural information of mesoporous interweaving, this amorphous carbon structure with porosity provides enhanced space for catalytic reactions (Fig. 2a , 2b). The diffusion diffraction ring images of selected area electron diffraction (SAED) revealed a typical amorphous state of the material (Fig. 2c). The element mapping of NC-900 demonstrated that nitrogen could be easily integrated into the carbon framework, with C, O, and N evenly superimposed and distributed within the material (Fig. 2d-f). The N2 adsorption-desorption curves of the catalyst NC-X all exhibit a closed type IV isotherm, with an H4-type hysteresis loop observed within the relative pressure range of 0.6–1.0 (Fig. 3a -d). Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) calculations indicate that the pore size distribution of NC-X falls between 6 and 9 nm, typical of a mesoporous structure. The material obtained through pyrolysis at 900 °C exhibits the largest specific surface area, with a BET surface area of 244 m2·g −1 and a pore volume of 1.8 cm3·g −1. As the pyrolysis temperature of NC-X increases, the specific surface area of the catalyst gradually enlarges. It is generally believed that the high specific surface area of the catalyst enhances the exposure of catalytic active centers and facilitates mass transfer, ultimately leading to improved reaction activity [43]. To gain a deeper understanding of the relationship between elemental composition and reaction activity, we conducted X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis on the surface elements of the catalyst NC-X. The results indicate the presence of N, O, and C elements on the surface of NC-900, as shown in Fig. S1a. Detailed analysis of the high-resolution N 1 s spectra of NC-900 is fitted into four peaks, corresponding to pyridinic N (≈398.3 eV), pyrrolic N (≈399.6 eV), graphitic N (≈401.0 eV), and N-oxide forms (≈402.6 eV), respectively (Fig. 4a ) [46-48]. With the increase in pyrolysis temperature from 600 °C to 900 °C, it is observed that the content of pyridinic N decreases while the content of graphitic N gradually increases. This suggests that graphitic N is more stable than pyridinic N and that the latter may undergo transformation into the former at higher temperatures. The addition of inorganic templates introduces a certain amount of elemental oxygen into the catalyst. XPS analysis reveals the high-resolution O 1 s spectra of NC-900 can be deconvoluted into four peaks, originating from C = O (≈531.6 eV), COH (≈532.5 eV), CO-C (≈533.4 eV) and O = CO (≈534.5 eV) (Fig. 4b) [49,50]. The C 1 s spectrum displays four peaks centered at the binding energies of 284.7, 285.7, 286.1, and 288.3 eV, assigned to C = C, CN, CO, and C = O (Fig. S1b) [51,52]. Notably, the content of graphitic N increases with the rise in pyrolysis temperature, and this increase is positively correlated with the yield of product 2a, as shown in Fig. 4c, Fig. S2-S4, and Table S2. Pyridinic nitrogen and pyrrolic nitrogen are typical edge nitrogens that may be the main reasons for the enhanced activity [37,38,40,53]. We studied the correlation between the combined ratio of pyridinic and pyrrolic sites and the reaction results. The findings revealed that the combined ratio of these nitrogen species does not promote the selectivity or yield of product 2a (Fig. 4d). Previous research has demonstrated that incorporating N species into carbon-based catalysts prompts the relocation of electrons, thereby activating oxygen molecules and substrates during oxidation reactions [54]. Therefore, we speculate that the exceptional catalytic performance of NC-900 can be attributed to the enhanced presence of graphitic N species with high electron density and the promotion of the reaction by the indispensable mesoporous structure. 3.3 Substrate scope To investigate the substrate scope of metal-free NC-900 catalyzed aerobic oxidation of alcohols, we tested various benzyl alcohols with different structures and obtained the desired aldehydes in moderate to high yields, as shown in Scheme 1. Benzyl alcohols containing mono-substituted or multi-substituted methoxy groups were synthesized into their corresponding benzaldehydes with good yields (2a-2d). For the methyl-substituted derivatives, the oxidation products of para-substituted and meta-substituted benzyl alcohols exhibited slightly higher yields than ortho-substituted benzyl alcohols (2e-2g), possibly due to the influence of steric hindrance effects. Benzyl alcohols with isopropyl and tert‑butyl groups also obtained 2h and 2i with yields of 79 % and 99 %, respectively. Benzyl alcohol provided the 2j in 91 % yield. Using halogenated benzyl alcohol as a substrate, no dehalogenation was observed. The experimental findings indicate that the catalytic system is tolerable to mono-halogenated benzyl alcohol (2k-2n). For strong electron-withdrawing groups such as -NO2 and -CF3, the corresponding aldehydes (2o, 2p) were provided with a 71 % and 83 % yield. Substrates possessing electron-donating groups displayed superior yields of products in contrast to those containing electron-withdrawing groups. It is hypothesized that the reaction process is influenced by electronic effects. Detailed studies on these electronic effects were conducted using Hammett plots (Fig. S6). Kinetic experiments were performed on p-substituted primary alcohols, and a linear relationship was observed between the relative rates and substituent constants, with a ρ value of −0.85. The findings unambiguously demonstrate that the presence of electron-donating substituents in the substrate enhances the favorability of the reaction. The pyridine and thiophen derivatives can be synthesized into the target products (2q-2s). It is noteworthy that 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, 1t), an important renewable platform chemical derived from biomass, exhibits tolerance to the catalytic system and can be smoothly converted into the widely used 2,5-dimethylfuran (DFF, 2t) with a yield of 65 %. Furthermore, the challenging cinnamyl alcohol and 3-phenyl-2-propyn-1-ol successfully obtained the desired products 2u and 2v, with yields of moderate, respectively. 3.4 Practicability and reusability of the catalyst To emphasize the practical significance of the new method, we performed a scaled-up experiment utilizing the standard reaction condition (Fig. 5a ). Using 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol and 2-thiophenemethanol as substrates, the corresponding aldehydes were successfully synthesized with excellent yields. Substrates containing electron-withdrawing groups also demonstrate good selectivity at the gram-scale level, achieving moderate yields. The versatility of the catalyst NC-900 was further evaluated through multi-step and one-pot reaction sequences. In the reaction utilizing methanol as the solvent, benzaldehyde can serve as an intermediate to produce high-value-added methyl benzoate through a tandem reaction. When aniline is introduced into the reaction, the catalytic system can also facilitate the one-pot synthesis of N-benzylideneanilin with a yield of 59 % (Fig. 5b). The processes successfully achieved the synthesis of the desired products, fully demonstrating the compatibility and versatility of the metal-free catalyst NC-900. The recycling capability of the NC-900 catalyst was evaluated. After the standard reaction, the catalyst was recovered using a simple method and washed with anhydrous methanol. It was then dried and used in the next cycle experiment. The results indicated that after five consecutive uses, the yield of 2a remained stable at approximately 80 %, with a selectivity towards the target product exceeding 85 % (Fig. 5c). This demonstrates the excellent stability of the NC-900 catalyst. The XRD characterization of the catalyst NC-900-cycle shows that the diffraction peak has almost no obvious change (Fig. S7). Further XPS characterization provided insights into the chemical element composition and bonding states. The analysis revealed a slight decrease in the content of graphitic N and an increase in the content of oxidized N in the catalyst after recycling (Fig. 5d). This may be attributed to the partial conversion of graphitic N into oxidized N during the reaction process [55], leading to a slight decrease in catalytic activity in the recycling experiments, which is consistent with the conjecture that graphitic N is used as the active site for the aerobic oxidation of alcohols. As shown in Table S3, compared to previously reported metal-free nitrogen-doped materials, NC-900 as a biomass-derived nitrogen-doped carbon material, has maintained excellent catalytic performance in the reaction, achieving high selectivity and yield of the target product. 3.5 Reaction mechanism To elucidate the mechanism of the reaction, a series of mechanistic experiments were conducted. Initially, we investigated the effects of radical scavengers to identify the reactive oxygen species involved in the reaction (Scheme S1). Compared with standard reactions without scavengers, the addition of 2,6-di‑tert‑butyl‑4-methylphenol resulted in a significant reduction in 2a yield of only 24 %, suggesting that the free radical mechanism is involved in the catalytic process. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) results revealed the existence of characteristic peaks for the DMPO-superoxide radical adduct (Fig. 6a ), providing further evidence that ·O2 − serves as the reactive oxygen species responsible for the aerobic oxidation of primary alcohols [56]. The conversion rate of primary alcohol and the yield of carbonyl compounds were continuously monitored using gas chromatography (Fig. 6b). Throughout the entire reaction process, the consumption of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol was nearly quantitative, with the desired aldehyde being the sole product and no corresponding acid formation observed. Plotting the conversion rate or yield as a function of time revealed a nearly linear trend. Kinetic experiments revealed that the reaction rate constant for the oxidation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol is 0.23 h−1 (Fig. 6c). The apparent activation energy (EA) was calculated to be 43.4 kJ·mol−1 based on the Arrhenius plot (Fig. 6d). According to the above radical inhibition experiments and kinetic experiments, we can provide a possible reaction mechanism for the oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes over the NC-900 catalyst. The defects caused by N doping can adsorb molecular oxygen, and graphitic-N has a higher electronegativity that accelerates electron transfer through the alteration of charge distribution, thereby enhancing the activation of molecular oxygen and converting it into superoxide radicals. Subsequently, the formed superoxide radicals acquire hydrogen from the α-carbon of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol adsorbed on the carbon material surface through π-π interaction [34], resulting in the formation of p-anisaldehyde. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully prepared a heterogeneous nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst for the selective oxidation of various functionality aromatic, heterocyclic, allylic, propargylic primary to carbonyl compounds in good to excellent selectivity. Catalyst characterization and control experiments have demonstrated that graphitic N exhibits exceptional catalytic activity, and the mesoporous structure facilitates the progress of the reaction. Based on the Arrhenius plot the apparent activation energy of the reaction is 43.4 kJ·mol−1. This work not only provides a novel idea for the selective oxidation of alcohols but also broadens the application domain of nitrogen-doped carbon materials. coredata.dc:description: The selective oxidation of alcohols to carbonyl compounds is a crucial reaction in organic chemistry. In this study, we report the synthesis of nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon material by hard template method using biomass derivative sucrose and melamine as carbon and nitrogen sources and silica sol as template agent. Using molecular oxygen as the oxidant, the obtained NC-900 exhibits excellent selectivity in the oxidation of primary alcohols to the corresponding aldehydes without generating over-oxidized acid. For example, under optimal reaction conditions, 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol is almost quantitatively converted to 4-methoxybenzaldehyde. The catalytic system showed robust tolerance to sensitive functional groups and demonstrated favorable reaction effects in gram-scale experiments and multi-step, one-pot reaction sequences. The catalyst was reused for 5 times, and its catalytic activity did not decrease significantly. Hammett correlation studies indicated that the reaction favored substrates with electron-donating substituents. Characterization and experimental results indicate that the synergistic effect of graphitic N and mesoporous structure plays a pivotal role in enhancing the catalytic activity of NC-900 in this transformation. The mechanism study shows that the reaction involves free radical process.
